00039 namespace boost
00040 {
00041   // Used as a default template argument internally, merely to
00042   // indicate "use the default", this can also be passed by users
00043   // explicitly in order to specify that the default should be used.
00044   struct use_default;
00045   
00046 # ifndef BOOST_NO_TEMPLATE_PARTIAL_SPECIALIZATION
00047   // the incompleteness of use_default causes massive problems for
00048   // is_convertible (naturally).  This workaround is fortunately not
00049   // needed for vc6/vc7.
00050   template<class To>
00051   struct is_convertible<use_default,To>
00052     : mpl::false_ {};
00053 # endif 
00054   
00055   namespace detail
00056   {
00057 
00058     // 
00059     // Result type used in enable_if_convertible meta function.
00060     // This can be an incomplete type, as only pointers to 
00061     // enable_if_convertible< ... >::type are used.
00062     // We could have used void for this, but conversion to
00063     // void* is just to easy.
00064     //
00065     struct enable_type;
00066   }
00067 
00068 
00069   //
00070   // enable_if for use in adapted iterators constructors.
00071   //
00072   // In order to provide interoperability between adapted constant and
00073   // mutable iterators, adapted iterators will usually provide templated
00074   // conversion constructors of the following form
00075   //
00076   // template <class BaseIterator>
00077   // class adapted_iterator :
00078   //   public iterator_adaptor< adapted_iterator<Iterator>, Iterator >
00079   // {
00080   // public:
00081   //   
00082   //   ...
00083   //
00084   //   template <class OtherIterator>
00085   //   adapted_iterator(
00086   //       OtherIterator const& it
00087   //     , typename enable_if_convertible<OtherIterator, Iterator>::type* = 0);
00088   //
00089   //   ...
00090   // };
00091   //
00092   // enable_if_convertible is used to remove those overloads from the overload
00093   // set that cannot be instantiated. For all practical purposes only overloads
00094   // for constant/mutable interaction will remain. This has the advantage that
00095   // meta functions like boost::is_convertible do not return false positives,
00096   // as they can only look at the signature of the conversion constructor
00097   // and not at the actual instantiation.
00098   //
00099   // enable_if_interoperable can be safely used in user code. It falls back to
00100   // always enabled for compilers that don't support enable_if or is_convertible. 
00101   // There is no need for compiler specific workarounds in user code. 
00102   //
00103   // The operators implementation relies on boost::is_convertible not returning
00104   // false positives for user/library defined iterator types. See comments
00105   // on operator implementation for consequences.
00106   //
00107 #  if defined(BOOST_NO_IS_CONVERTIBLE) || defined(BOOST_NO_SFINAE)
00108   
00109   template <class From, class To>
00110   struct enable_if_convertible
00111   {
00112       typedef detail::enable_type type;
00113   };
00114   
00115 #  elif BOOST_WORKAROUND(_MSC_FULL_VER, BOOST_TESTED_AT(13102292)) && BOOST_MSVC > 1300
00116   
00117   // For some reason vc7.1 needs us to "cut off" instantiation
00118   // of is_convertible in a few cases.
00119   template<typename From, typename To>
00120   struct enable_if_convertible
00121     : iterators::enable_if<
00122         mpl::or_<
00123             is_same<From,To>
00124           , is_convertible<From, To>
00125         >
00126       , detail::enable_type
00127     >
00128   {};
00129   
00130 #  else 
00131   
00132   template<typename From, typename To>
00133   struct enable_if_convertible
00134     : iterators::enable_if<
00135           is_convertible<From, To>
00136         , detail::enable_type
00137       >
00138   {};
00139       
00140 # endif
00141   
00142   //
00143   // Default template argument handling for iterator_adaptor
00144   //
00145   namespace detail
00146   {
00147     // If T is use_default, return the result of invoking
00148     // DefaultNullaryFn, otherwise return T.
00149     template <class T, class DefaultNullaryFn>
00150     struct ia_dflt_help
00151       : mpl::apply_if<
00152             is_same<T, use_default>
00153           , DefaultNullaryFn
00154           , mpl::identity<T>
00155         >
00156     {
00157     };
00158 
00159     // A metafunction which computes an iterator_adaptor's base class,
00160     // a specialization of iterator_facade.
00161     template <
00162         class Derived
00163       , class Base
00164       , class Value
00165       , class Traversal
00166       , class Reference
00167       , class Difference
00168     >
00169     struct iterator_adaptor_base
00170     {
00171         typedef iterator_facade<
00172             Derived
00173             
00174 # ifdef BOOST_ITERATOR_REF_CONSTNESS_KILLS_WRITABILITY
00175           , typename detail::ia_dflt_help<
00176                 Value
00177               , mpl::apply_if<
00178                     is_same<Reference,use_default>
00179                   , iterator_value<Base>
00180                   , remove_reference<Reference>
00181                 >
00182             >::type
00183 # else
00184           , typename detail::ia_dflt_help<
00185                 Value, iterator_value<Base>
00186             >::type
00187 # endif
00188             
00189           , typename detail::ia_dflt_help<
00190                 Traversal
00191               , iterator_traversal<Base>
00192             >::type
00193 
00194           , typename detail::ia_dflt_help<
00195                 Reference
00196               , mpl::apply_if<
00197                     is_same<Value,use_default>
00198                   , iterator_reference<Base>
00199                   , add_reference<Value>
00200                 >
00201             >::type
00202 
00203           , typename detail::ia_dflt_help<
00204                 Difference, iterator_difference<Base>
00205             >::type
00206         >
00207         type;
00208     };
00209     template <class T> int static_assert_convertible_to(T);
00210   }
00211   
00212   //
00213   // Iterator Adaptor
00214   //
00215   // The parameter ordering changed slightly with respect to former
00216   // versions of iterator_adaptor The idea is that when the user needs
00217   // to fiddle with the reference type it is highly likely that the
00218   // iterator category has to be adjusted as well.  Any of the
00219   // following four template arguments may be ommitted or explicitly
00220   // replaced by use_default.
00221   //
00222   //   Value - if supplied, the value_type of the resulting iterator, unless
00223   //      const. If const, a conforming compiler strips constness for the
00224   //      value_type. If not supplied, iterator_traits<Base>::value_type is used
00225   //
00226   //   Category - the traversal category of the resulting iterator. If not
00227   //      supplied, iterator_traversal<Base>::type is used.
00228   //
00229   //   Reference - the reference type of the resulting iterator, and in
00230   //      particular, the result type of operator*(). If not supplied but
00231   //      Value is supplied, Value& is used. Otherwise
00232   //      iterator_traits<Base>::reference is used.
00233   //
00234   //   Difference - the difference_type of the resulting iterator. If not
00235   //      supplied, iterator_traits<Base>::difference_type is used.
00236   //
00237   template <
00238       class Derived
00239     , class Base
00240     , class Value        = use_default
00241     , class Traversal    = use_default
00242     , class Reference    = use_default
00243     , class Difference   = use_default
00244   >
00245   class iterator_adaptor
00246     : public detail::iterator_adaptor_base<
00247         Derived, Base, Value, Traversal, Reference, Difference
00248       >::type
00249   {
00250       friend class iterator_core_access;
00251 
00252       typedef typename detail::iterator_adaptor_base<
00253           Derived, Base, Value, Traversal, Reference, Difference
00254       >::type super_t;
00255 
00256    public:
00257       iterator_adaptor() {}
00258 
00259       explicit iterator_adaptor(Base const &iter)
00260           : m_iterator(iter)
00261       {
00262       }
00263 
00264       Base const& base() const
00265         { return m_iterator; }
00266 
00267    protected:
00268       //
00269       // lvalue access to the Base object for Derived
00270       //
00271       Base const& base_reference() const
00272         { return m_iterator; }
00273 
00274       Base& base_reference()
00275         { return m_iterator; }
00276 
00277    private:
00278       //
00279       // Core iterator interface for iterator_facade.  This is private
00280       // to prevent temptation for Derived classes to use it, which
00281       // will often result in an error.  Derived classes should use
00282       // base_reference(), above, to get direct access to m_iterator.
00283       // 
00284       typename super_t::reference dereference() const
00285         { return *m_iterator; }
00286 
00287       template <
00288       class OtherDerived, class OtherIterator, class V, class C, class R, class D
00289       >   
00290       bool equal(iterator_adaptor<OtherDerived, OtherIterator, V, C, R, D> const& x) const
00291       {
00292         // Maybe readd with same_distance
00293         //           BOOST_STATIC_ASSERT(
00294         //               (detail::same_category_and_difference<Derived,OtherDerived>::value)
00295         //               );
00296           return m_iterator == x.base();
00297       }
00298 
00299       typedef typename iterator_category_to_traversal<
00300           typename super_t::iterator_category
00301       >::type my_traversal;
00302 
00303 # define BOOST_ITERATOR_ADAPTOR_ASSERT_TRAVERSAL(cat) \
00304       typedef int assertion[sizeof(detail::static_assert_convertible_to<cat>(my_traversal()))];
00305 //      BOOST_STATIC_ASSERT((is_convertible<my_traversal,cat>::value));
00306 
00307       void advance(typename super_t::difference_type n)
00308       {
00309           BOOST_ITERATOR_ADAPTOR_ASSERT_TRAVERSAL(random_access_traversal_tag)
00310           m_iterator += n;
00311       }
00312   
00313       void increment() { ++m_iterator; }
00314 
00315       void decrement() 
00316       {
00317           BOOST_ITERATOR_ADAPTOR_ASSERT_TRAVERSAL(bidirectional_traversal_tag)
00318            --m_iterator;
00319       }
00320 
00321       template <
00322           class OtherDerived, class OtherIterator, class V, class C, class R, class D
00323       >   
00324       typename super_t::difference_type distance_to(
00325           iterator_adaptor<OtherDerived, OtherIterator, V, C, R, D> const& y) const
00326       {
00327           BOOST_ITERATOR_ADAPTOR_ASSERT_TRAVERSAL(random_access_traversal_tag)
00328           // Maybe readd with same_distance
00329           //           BOOST_STATIC_ASSERT(
00330           //               (detail::same_category_and_difference<Derived,OtherDerived>::value)
00331           //               );
00332           return y.base() - m_iterator;
00333       }
00334 
00335 # undef BOOST_ITERATOR_ADAPTOR_ASSERT_TRAVERSAL
00336       
00337    private: // data members
00338       Base m_iterator;
00339   };
00340 
00341 } // namespace boost
